citations.narrative:
During the inspection. a young red fox's right front foot became caught between the caging and the floor of its enclosure.
The inspector and facility representative had left the mammal building where the fox was seen free roaming its enclosure
and approximately 5 minutes later heard the fox vocalizing. Once the inspector and facility representative walked towards
the enclosure, the fox stopped vocalizing and laid down until the representative could free its foot approximately 1 minute
after identifying the fox was stuck. Once freed, the fox did not limp and no soft tissue injuries were found by the
representative. Enclosures that allow for animal's body parts to become entrapped may lead to elongated distress and
possible injury to the animal. The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained
in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals.

On the empty mammal food shelf that was an accumulation of rodent droppings. The facility does not currently have any
program of pest control in place in this building. The presence of insect and mammal pests may create a disease hazard
to the animal. A safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests shall
be established and maintained.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
3.125(a)  Repeat
   
Facilities, general. 
During the inspection. a young red fox's right front foot became caught between the caging and the floor of its enclosure. 
The inspector and facility representative had left the mammal building where the fox was seen free roaming its enclosure 
and approximately 5 minutes later heard the fox vocalizing. Once the inspector and facility representative walked towards 
the enclosure, the fox stopped vocalizing and laid down until the representative could free its foot approximately 1 minute 
after identifying the fox was stuck. Once freed, the fox did not limp and no soft tissue injuries were found by the 
representative. Enclosures that allow for animal's body parts to become entrapped may lead to elongated distress and 
possible injury to the animal. The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained 
in good repair to protect the animals from injury and to contain the animals. 
3.131(d)  Repeat
   
Sanitation. 
On the empty mammal food shelf that was an accumulation of rodent droppings. The facility does not currently have any 
program of pest control in place in this building. The presence of insect and mammal pests may create a disease hazard 
to the animal. A safe and effective program for the control of insects, ectoparasites, and avian and mammalian pests shall 
be established and maintained. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.

species.common: RED FOX (INCLUDES SILVER FOX & CROSS FOX)
